1:
My son, if you set aside your money as a guarantee for your neighbor's loan,\q if you gave your promise for a loan of someone you do not know,
\q
2:
then you have laid a trap for yourself by your promise\q and you have been caught by the words of your mouth.


\q
4:
Give your eyes no sleep\q and your eyelids no slumber.
\q
5:
Save yourself like a gazelle from the hand of the hunter,\q like a bird from the hand of the fowler.


\q
6:
Look at the ant, you lazy person,\q consider her ways, and be wise.
\q
7:
It has no commander,\q officer, or ruler,
\q
8:
yet it prepares its food in the summer\q and during the harvest it stores up what it will eat.


\q
9:
How long will you sleep, you lazy person?\q When will you rise from your sleep?
\q
10:
"A little sleep, a little slumber,\q a little folding of the hands to rest"—
\q
11:
and your poverty will come like a robber\q and your needs like an armed soldier.


\q
12:
A worthless person—a wicked man—\q lives by the crookedness of his speech,
\q
13:
winking his eyes, making signals with his feet\q and pointing with his fingers.


\q
14:
He plots evil with deceit in his heart;\q he always stirs up discord.
\q
15:
Therefore his disaster will overtake him in an instant;\q in a moment he will be broken beyond healing.


\q
16:
There are six things that Yahweh hates,\q seven that are disgusting to him.
\q
17:
The eyes of a proud person, a tongue that lies,\q hands that shed the blood of innocent people,
\q
18:
a heart that invents wicked schemes,\q feet that quickly run to do evil,
\q
19:
a witness who breathes out lies\q and one who sows discord among brothers.


\q
20:
My son, obey the command of your father\q and do not forsake the teaching of your mother.
\q
21:
Always bind them on your heart;\q tie them about your neck.


\q
23:
For the commands are a lamp, and the teaching is a light;\q the corrections that come by instruction are the way of life.


\q
24:
It keeps you from the immoral woman,\q from the smooth words of an immoral woman.
\q
25:
Do not lust in your heart after her beauty\q and do not let her capture you with her eyelashes.

\q
26:
Sleeping with a prostitute can cost the price of a loaf of bread,\q but the wife of another may cost you your very life.
\q
27:
Can a man carry a fire against his chest\q without burning his clothes?


\q
28:
Can a man walk on hot coals\q without scorching his feet?
\q
29:
So is the man who sleeps with his neighbor's wife;\q the one who sleeps with her will not go unpunished.


\q
30:
People do not despise a thief if he steals\q to satisfy his need when he is hungry.
\q
31:
Yet if he is caught, he will pay back seven times what he stole;\q he must give up everything of value in his house.


\q
32:
The one who commits adultery has no sense;\q the one who does it destroys himself.
\q
33:
Wounds and shame are what he deserves\q and his disgrace will not be wiped away.


\q
34:
For jealousy makes a man furious;\q he will show no mercy when he takes his revenge.
\q
35: He will accept no compensation\q and he cannot be bought off, though you offer him many gifts.
